title: STREAM Games to Your Switch!
description: Only 2 DAYS LEFT to get the LIMITED EDITION "Designed By Linus" Techlinked Shirt:  More Techlinked Merch:   Twitter:  Instagram:  Facebook:   NEWS SOURCES:  SWITCH GOES STREAMING   @ 0:30  FACEBOOK + QUALCOMM TEAM UP    ROBOTS LEARN FROM WATCHING   @ 0:05 + 0:30  QUICK BITS  TESLA SOURCE CODE   THE TESLA OF TRUCKS   @ 0:47  BATTLEFIELD V IS A TEASE   HIDE YO TEENS   FAKE SKYDIVING GETS MORE REAL
transcript: What? There's tech news today even? Dennis? Yes? What? I'm the News! Algh, tech news happens a lot. The Nintendo Switch is notoriously underpowerd compared to its console peers, which means it can be difficult to port graphics intensive titles to it. but Nintendo is getting around that by just streaming them. This week, Japan is getting an exclusive 'cloud version' of Resident Evil 7 that only downloads that only downloads 45 MB of assets. The rest of the game is streamed via the internet. And it's actually not the only streaming game for the switch, Fantasy Star Online 2 is also playable this way. Kind of defeats the purpose of having a portable system if you have to stay on a strong wifi connection to play a game, but hey, Nintendo does what it wants. They'r a beautiful, confusing creature. Facebook has enlisted the help of Qualcomm in developing their gigabit wifi system, known as the Teragraph Project. The project is described as multi-node wireless system focused on bringing high speed internet connectivity to dense urban areas Qualcomm will be tasked with integrating chips into the system that can send data at the 60 GHz frequency, which can transmit at higher speeds although the signals get more easily blocked by obstacles. more speed is good, but should we really be enthusiastic about sending more of our data through a pipeline set up by the lizard man? He lives for gobbling up your data. *slurping sounds* I love that data Oehhhh And they're still here to take your gerbs(?). That's right. I'm talking about robots. Researchers at nVidia have developed a system that can teach an AI to perform actions, simply be observing a human perform said actions. In an example, a researcher stacks blocks in a certain order which are then restacked by the robot in the same order. The robot wasn't actually taught the stacking action, this is great progress. The catch is, we have to make sure no-one shoots anybody in front of the robot. It's very impressionable, so ok guys, no shooting eachother in the office this week. Trevor!!! Dang I'm looking at you! Ok, what were we doing? Oh yeah, Quickbits, it's brought to you by, you guessed it: The designed by LInus shirt. It has to be, because there's only two days left to get it. And then it'll be gone, forever. You wouldn't want this priceless piece of TechLinked history to pass into memory, would you? I mean, maybe you would, that's understandable, it's just tape over a logo. But you can also get brand-new TechLinked merch as well, so click the link in the description to gear up. My dudes. Tesla is finally releasing some of the source code associated with its car tech, which has been an issue, because it's built on Linux, under the general public license. Which says anybody can use and modify it, provided they release their source code. But Tesla didn't, and now they have. After six years, but look, Elon has been kind of busy guys, You want spaceships, or you want a source code? I'll take an X-Wing please, thanks. Speaking of Tesla, they don't really make electric trucks, yet. So a company called Rivian is developing a fully electric all-wheel drive pick-up truck and SUV. To romp around the back-woods in complete silence, and with zero emissions. The forest folk will love it. EA teased the next entry in the Battlefield franchise, Battlefield V, with a super-short clip of someone presumably getting stabbed, in what is presumably a WWII setting. Fans might be upset, but at least this might be slightly more historically accurate. TeenSafe, an app that lets parents monitor their kid's digital activity has had a leak of user data. Including usernames and passwords, after they stored their data on an unprotected Amazon server. And Eyefly, an indoor skydiving windtunnel company has introduced VR into 28 of its 37 locations, so you can feel like you're skydiving, even more. But you're not really skydiving, you wussy. Hey, guess what, that's it for TechLinked guys, thanks for watching, subscribe if you want to, hit the bell icon if you want to, If you don't want to do that, well, I can't make you, and I wouldn't want to anyway. So let's all agree to only do things we wanna do, what I only want to do; is eat cheeseburgers, though. So, this concept needs some work. You liked that Dennis? You liked that joke?
